questions.question: Does the headline tell me exactly what you sell and why I should care?
questions.exact_fix: Make the first headline say what you sell and why it matters
questions.reason:
The homepage does not show a clear, user-facing headline above the fold that explicitly states what is sold and why it matters. The only H1 shown is a hidden placeholder string, and the above-the-fold area appears to be navigation and a slider without an explicit value-prop headline. DESKTOP_HTML_CHUNK 01 shows H1 as hidden: "

homepage.heading1.storeid=2

" and no clear hero headline; MOBILE_HTML_CHUNK 01 shows the same hidden H1. DESKTOP_VISIBLE_TEXT/MOBILE_VISIBLE_TEXT above-the-fold content is navigation + category links and does not present a clear headline/value prop.

questions.question: The main product benefit or differentiator is clearly stated in the first screen (above the fold)
questions.exact_fix: State the main benefit clearly in the first screen
questions.reason: A clear, specific main product benefit/differentiator is not stated in the first screen as a hero message. The visible copy is mostly navigation and category/menu items; benefit-style statements like "Blerje të sigurta" appear as section headings but are not clearly evidenced as being in the first screen (above the fold). DESKTOP_VISIBLE_TEXT and MOBILE_VISIBLE_TEXT show navigation and categories first; "Blerje të sigurta" appears but the evidence does not confirm it is visible without scrolling. DESKTOP_HTML_CHUNK 04/MOBILE_HTML_CHUNK 04 show "shop-with-confidence" section exists, but no proof it is above-the-fold on initial load.

questions.question: Does the homepage become usable within 3 seconds, with no major layout shifts or delays?
questions.exact_fix: Improve load speed and remove layout shifts on first load
questions.reason: No Lighthouse or equivalent performance metrics (load time/LCP) are provided in the evidence, so the under-3-seconds requirement cannot be verified. No Lighthouse/speed test data present in DESKTOP_FEATURES_JSON, MOBILE_FEATURES_JSON, HTML chunks, or visible text.

questions.question: Are the product's main function and its biggest benefit clearly stated or implied when a product page loads.
questions.bar_chart_category: Clear Use Case For Target Audience
questions.exact_fix: State the main benefit clearly as soon as the product page loads
questions.reason: The product function (chair) is clear from the title, but the biggest benefit/value proposition is not clearly communicated above the fold; the immediate area shows price, warranty, payment/shipping, and a long description appears below (requires scrolling/reading). DESKTOP_VISIBLE_TEXT shows H1 "Karrige SENSE7 Spellcaster, e zezë" and pricing/other details but no clear primary benefit statement near top; benefit-focused copy appears in the description section ("Përshkrimi... STABILITET DHE ERGONOMI") which is below tabs (requires scrolling): DESKTOP_VISIBLE_TEXT, MOBILE_VISIBLE_TEXT.

questions.question: Does the page clearly describe the 'ideal user' and the specific situation where this product works best?
questions.bar_chart_category: Clear Use Case For Target Audience
questions.exact_fix: Describe the ideal user and best use case in simple terms
questions.reason: The page does not clearly identify an ideal user or specific situation near the top; buyers must infer it from the later description text. Above-the-fold content lists title, rating count, warranty, code, price, payments, shipping; no explicit ideal-user targeting visible: DESKTOP_VISIBLE_TEXT, MOBILE_VISIBLE_TEXT. Use-case language is inside the description section ("CILËN KARRIGE LOJËRASH..."), which is not immediate: DESKTOP_VISIBLE_TEXT.

questions.question: The mini-cart or cart page offers 1-click "Frequently Bought Together" additions to increase order size before the final checkout.
questions.exact_fix: Add simple one click add ons in cart to increase order value
questions.reason: No “Frequently Bought Together” / cross-sell add-on section is visible in the mini-cart or cart page, and there are no one-click related product add-ons near the subtotal/checkout area. Cart page shows product list, FLEX option, coupon/giftcard inputs, totals, and checkout/login CTA but no recommended items section (DESKTOP_VISIBLE_TEXT, MOBILE_VISIBLE_TEXT; DESKTOP_HTML_CHUNK 03-04; MOBILE_HTML_CHUNK 03-04).

questions.question: All fees (e.g., tax, shipping) are shown before the final checkout screen.
questions.exact_fix: Show shipping and taxes before the final payment step
questions.reason: The order summary shows a clear cost breakdown (subtotal, shipping, tax, discount) and total during checkout, before purchase submission, on both desktop and mobile. DESKTOP_HTML_CHUNK 05 shows order totals with “Nëntotali”, “Transporti”, “TVSH 18%”, “Duke përfshirë zbritjen”, and “Total”. MOBILE_VISIBLE_TEXT also shows the same breakdown and total before payment submission.

questions.question: The checkout page loads without delay and is visually stable within 3 seconds.
questions.exact_fix: Improve checkout load speed and prevent layout shifts
questions.reason: Page load time within 3 seconds and visual stability cannot be verified from the provided HTML/text evidence. Only static HTML/visible text is provided; no performance timing or layout shift evidence is included (DESKTOP_HTML_CHUNK 01-05, MOBILE_HTML_CHUNK 01-05, DESKTOP_VISIBLE_TEXT, MOBILE_VISIBLE_TEXT).

questions.question: Is a buyer-relevant problem or frustration mentioned in the headline or subheadline?
questions.exact_fix: Add a clear buyer problem statement in the headline or subheadline
questions.reason: The homepage does not explicitly state a specific customer problem being solved immediately on load. The content shown focuses on navigation/categories and general reassurance, not a defined customer pain point. DESKTOP_VISIBLE_TEXT/MOBILE_VISIBLE_TEXT show navigation and general statements like "Blerje të sigurta" but no explicit problem statement. DESKTOP_HTML_CHUNK 01 and MOBILE_HTML_CHUNK 01 do not show a problem-focused headline/subheadline above the fold.

questions.question: Above the fold, the visual hierarchy makes the headline and primary CTA the most dominant elements, with no competing blocks that distract from the first click
questions.exact_fix: Remove distractions so the headline and main button stand out first
questions.reason: The above-the-fold structure appears to prioritize header navigation (logo/search/icons) and category menus/slider rather than clearly emphasizing the product’s core function/outcome with dominant functional messaging. DESKTOP_HTML_CHUNK 01 and MOBILE_HTML_CHUNK 01 show large header/navigation elements and category menu structure; DESKTOP_VISIBLE_TEXT begins with navigation/category labels rather than a dominant product function/outcome statement.

questions.question: An aggregate star rating (e.g., "4.8/5 Stars") or social proof (Used by 5,000+ people) is visible near the top of the home page.
questions.exact_fix: Add visible proof near the first screen, close to the main action
questions.reason: No aggregate star rating or clear usage-count social proof is shown above the fold in the provided evidence. DESKTOP_VISIBLE_TEXT/MOBILE_VISIBLE_TEXT contain no "4.x/5" star rating or "Used by X" style count above the fold. DESKTOP_FEATURES_JSON notes review signals generally, but provides no visible above-the-fold proof element.

questions.question: Is the star rating located immediately above or below the product price or main description?
questions.exact_fix: Place star rating close to the price and buy button
questions.reason: The star rating and review count appear in the same buy-box cluster immediately above the price area on both desktop and mobile. Rating block "2 (3 Vlerësime)" appears directly before the price lines "259.50 € 247.50 €" in the visible buy box: DESKTOP_VISIBLE_TEXT, MOBILE_VISIBLE_TEXT. Star icon present in HTML near rating: DESKTOP_HTML_CHUNK 05 ("icon-star-fill").

questions.question: The product page uses bullets, large text, or short paragraphs to make key details easy to skim on mobile.
questions.bar_chart_category: Clear Use Case For Target Audience
questions.exact_fix: Format key details so they are easy to skim on mobile
questions.reason: On mobile, key details are broken into short labeled sections and scannable bullet/line items (e.g., warranty/origin/code, shipping dates, and bulleted specs in the description). Mobile shows compact lines for key details and bullet-style dots in description/specs ("• Garancioni...", and "· Lartësia..." etc.): MOBILE_VISIBLE_TEXT. Tab labels (Përshkrimi/Detajet/Vlerësime) support scanability: MOBILE_VISIBLE_TEXT, MOBILE_HTML_CHUNK 05.

questions.question: General reviews or testimonials are easy to find and visible near the top of the product page.
questions.exact_fix: Make reviews easy to find near the top of the product page
questions.reason: Review signals are visible near the top via the star rating summary and review count next to the product title area, without needing heavy scrolling. Near product title, the rating summary "2 (3 Vlerësime)" is shown above the fold on both devices: DESKTOP_VISIBLE_TEXT, MOBILE_VISIBLE_TEXT.

questions.question: Does the main imagery show the specific result or 'after-state' the customer achieves by using the product?
questions.exact_fix: Show the specific result or after state the buyer is aiming for
questions.reason: The main imagery appears to show the product (chair) itself rather than an after-state or transformation/result achieved by using it. Product gallery shows only product photos (multiple images of the chair) with no explicit outcome/after-state imagery indicated: DESKTOP_HTML_CHUNK 04-05 (product-picture-slider images with alt "Karrige SENSE7 Spellcaster, e zezë"), MOBILE_HTML_CHUNK 04-05.

questions.question: The page proactively answers buyer questions about fit, sizing, compatibility, or expectations with an FAQ or similar section
questions.exact_fix: Answer common questions with an FAQ so objections are handled
questions.reason: The page includes practical expectation guidance via visible dimensions and user recommendations in the description (e.g., maximum load and recommended user height). Description includes "Ngarkesa maksimale: 150 kg" and "Lartësia e rekomanduar e përdoruesit: deri në 185 cm" which answer fit/expectation questions: DESKTOP_VISIBLE_TEXT, MOBILE_VISIBLE_TEXT.

questions.question: Can a user reach the shipping info screen without being forced to create a password or 'Sign In'?
questions.exact_fix: Allow buyers to reach shipping without being forced to sign in
questions.reason: Users can access and fill the shipping details form without being required to sign in or create a password. DESKTOP_HTML_CHUNK 03-04 shows the shipping address form fields (name, last name, phone, city, address) directly on the checkout page with no password fields. MOBILE_HTML_CHUNK 03-04 shows the same shipping form. DESKTOP_VISIBLE_TEXT/MOBILE_VISIBLE_TEXT show the shipping step content without any sign-in wall.

questions.question: Are trust signals like ‘Secure Checkout,’ lock icons, or payment logos shown near credit card fields?
questions.exact_fix: Add clear payment trust cues near the card fields
questions.reason: No security/trust badges are shown near credit card/payment fields in the provided evidence, and the payment section shown does not include visible card entry fields. DESKTOP_HTML_CHUNK 04-05 and MOBILE_HTML_CHUNK 04-05 show the payment step area but no credit card fields or trust badges adjacent to payment inputs (payment method load area is empty/hidden input only).

questions.question: If a field is missed, the form shows the error clearly, instantly, and scrolls the user back to the problem area.
questions.exact_fix: Show clear errors and jump buyers back to the field that needs fixing
questions.reason: While validation messages and some error placeholders exist in the HTML, there is no evidence that errors appear instantly upon submission and that the page scrolls/jumps the user back to the exact problem field on both devices. DESKTOP_HTML_CHUNK 03-04 shows validation spans and some hidden error elements (e.g., “error-field ... hidden”), but no demonstrated behavior for instant error display or auto-scrolling. MOBILE_HTML_CHUNK 03-04 contains the same static elements without proof of scrolling behavior.

questions.question: On the homepage, is the primary CTA the most visually dominant element above the fold?
questions.exact_fix: Make the main button more obvious and more prominent
questions.reason: There is no single primary homepage CTA shown as the most visually prominent element above the fold; the visible interface is dominated by navigation, categories, and a banner slider. Product-level CTAs (e.g., "SHTO NË SHPORTË") appear later in the page content. DESKTOP_VISIBLE_TEXT/MOBILE_VISIBLE_TEXT show product CTAs "SHTO NË SHPORTË" in the "Oferta speciale" section, which appears after recommended products (not evidenced as above-the-fold). DESKTOP_HTML_CHUNK 01 and MOBILE_HTML_CHUNK 01 show header/nav and slider, not a dominant main CTA button.

questions.question: Do buyers have a clear and easy way to contact the company for questions, comments, concerns, or order information?
questions.exact_fix: Add a clear contact path, like email, chat, or contact page link
questions.reason: Buyers have clear contact options including live chat and footer contact details (email and phone). Phone and email are provided as tap-friendly links, and customer support responsiveness is implied by the statement that customers receive answers within seconds. DESKTOP_HTML_CHUNK 01 and MOBILE_HTML_CHUNK 01 show a visible "Chat" entry ("load-chat"). DESKTOP_FEATURES_JSON and MOBILE_FEATURES_JSON footer_links include "contact@gjirafa50.com" (mailto:) and "+383 38 616 161" (tel:). DESKTOP_VISIBLE_TEXT/MOBILE_VISIBLE_TEXT include "Kujdesi ndaj klientit" and "Prano përgjigje brenda sekondave" indicating response expectation.

questions.question: Technical details are easy to find in a dedicated section such as accordion tabs or specs, and are not buried inside long paragraphs
questions.bar_chart_category: Clear Use Case For Target Audience
questions.exact_fix: Make specs easy to find with short sections or tabs
questions.reason: Key benefits are not presented near the top as a concise bullet/icon benefit list; benefit content appears inside the long description section rather than a dedicated skimmable benefits block. Above-the-fold area shows pricing/shipping/payment info but not a benefit bullet list; benefits-like content is embedded in the description text further down: DESKTOP_VISIBLE_TEXT, MOBILE_VISIBLE_TEXT.

questions.question: Do the customer reviews specifically mention the same benefits or results that are promised in the product description?
questions.exact_fix: Encourage reviews that mention outcomes tied to the product promise
questions.reason: Customer review content is not visible in the provided evidence, so it can’t be verified that reviews mention the same benefits/results as the description. Evidence shows only rating summary and tab label "Vlerësime" but no actual review text content: DESKTOP_VISIBLE_TEXT, MOBILE_VISIBLE_TEXT; HTML shows review schema meta but not visible review statements: DESKTOP_HTML_CHUNK 04, MOBILE_HTML_CHUNK 04.

questions.question: The main checkout CTA uses language that matches the start of the next page
questions.exact_fix: Make the checkout button wording match what buyers see next
questions.reason: The main checkout CTA says “Kyçuni për të vazhduar” (Log in to continue) and points to a login URL, but the evidence does not include the next page content to confirm the CTA language matches what users see next. Checkout button text and destination: “Kyçuni për të vazhduar” with formaction "/account/login?returnUrl=%2Fcart" (DESKTOP_HTML_CHUNK 04; MOBILE_HTML_CHUNK 04). No login-page evidence provided.

questions.question: Checkout fields support browser autofill (e.g., address or contact info).
questions.exact_fix: Enable browser autofill to reduce typing and errors
questions.reason: The form fields do not show autocomplete attributes (e.g., autocomplete="name", "email", "address-line1"), so browser autofill support cannot be confidently verified for desktop and mobile. DESKTOP_HTML_CHUNK 03-04 shows inputs for name/phone/address without autocomplete attributes; the email field is present but hidden and also lacks autocomplete. MOBILE_HTML_CHUNK 03-04 mirrors this.

stage_summaries.summary:
The homepage currently underperforms at the Awareness stage because the first screen doesn’t quickly communicate what Gjirafa50 sells, why it’s valuable, or what problem it solves for the shopper. The headline and supporting copy are not explicit enough about the core offer and differentiator, and the above-the-fold area appears visually busy—competing elements reduce clarity and weaken the “first click” moment. In addition, the primary CTA is not the most dominant element, and there’s no immediate social proof (e.g., star rating, customer count) near the top to build trust fast. Together, these issues increase bounce rates and “confused exits,” meaning paid and organic traffic is less likely to move into browsing and product discovery—directly limiting top-of-funnel conversion and suppressing revenue from existing traffic.

From a business perspective, this is a revenue recovery opportunity because Awareness-stage improvements typically lift engagement without requiring more ad spend. Prioritize a clear, buyer-centric hero section: a single, specific headline that states the category and value (what you sell + why it matters), a subheadline that reflects a common shopper frustration (e.g., finding the right product fast, trusted delivery, best price), and one dominant primary CTA (e.g., “Shop Electronics,” “Browse Deals,” or “Search Products”) supported by a secondary option if needed. Reinforce credibility immediately with visible proof above the fold—aggregate rating, “trusted by X customers,” delivery/returns assurances, or “official warranty” messaging—placed close to the CTA. Finally, improve perceived speed and stability so the homepage becomes usable within ~3 seconds and avoids layout shifts; faster, steadier first loads protect conversion by keeping users engaged long enough to understand the offer and take the next step.

The Consideration-stage audit (44.4% overall) indicates that product pages on Gjirafa50 are not doing enough to help shoppers quickly understand *why* a product is the right choice for them. Key gaps include unclear articulation of the product’s primary function and biggest benefit at first load, limited guidance on who the product is best for and in what scenarios it performs best, and imagery that doesn’t consistently show the “after-state” outcome customers are trying to achieve. These issues increase cognitive load and uncertainty—two primary drivers of comparison shopping and drop-off—meaning you’re likely losing revenue to slower decision-making, higher bounce rates, and customers defaulting to competitors with clearer value communication.

To recover consideration-stage revenue, prioritize clarifying value and fit within the first screen of the product page. Add a concise “primary benefit” headline and 2–3 supporting bullets near the title/price (e.g., outcome-focused, not feature-heavy), plus a simple “Best for / Ideal for” module that frames the ideal user and top use cases in plain language. Upgrade the image stack to include at least one visual that communicates the result (e.g., lifestyle context, before/after where relevant, or a clear in-use demonstration) to reduce ambiguity and strengthen purchase confidence. Finally, make technical specs instantly scannable via a dedicated specs section or accordion tabs so customers can validate compatibility without hunting—this is especially important for electronics and appliances where spec friction directly delays or kills the purchase.

Customer reviews are currently an underused persuasion asset because they don’t reliably reinforce the same outcomes promised in the description. Introduce lightweight review prompts that ask buyers to comment on specific results (e.g., “What problem did this solve?” “What improved after using it?”), and surface “Most mentioned benefits” highlights near the buy section. Aligning product messaging, imagery, specs structure, and reviews around the same promised outcomes will shorten the decision cycle, improve add-to-cart rates, and reduce abandonment—creating a clear revenue recovery opportunity without requiring major changes to pricing or acquisition.

The Conversion stage on gjirafa50.com is currently underperforming (25% overall), with the biggest friction appearing at the cart and checkout—exactly where purchase intent is highest and drop-off is most costly. Key gaps include limited opportunities to increase order value (no simple “frequently bought together” or one-click add-ons in the cart) and a checkout call-to-action that doesn’t clearly set expectations for what happens next. These issues can reduce shopper confidence and momentum at the final step, leading to fewer completed orders and missed revenue from customers who were otherwise ready to buy.

On the checkout experience itself, the audit indicates performance and usability risks that commonly drive abandonment: the page needs to load quickly and remain visually stable within ~3 seconds, trust cues near payment fields are not prominent enough, and form handling is not optimized for error recovery and speed. When customers encounter slow loading, shifting layouts, unclear payment reassurance, or hard-to-fix form errors, they perceive higher risk and effort—especially on mobile—resulting in higher abandonment rates and lower conversion efficiency.

To recover revenue, prioritize improvements that reduce friction and increase confidence: introduce one-click cart add-ons (“Frequently Bought Together,” accessories, warranties) to lift average order value before checkout; align the primary checkout button wording with the next step (e.g., “Continue to Shipping” / “Continue to Payment”) to reduce uncertainty; and strengthen checkout fundamentals by improving load speed and layout stability, adding visible “Secure Checkout” and payment method logos near card inputs, and implementing clearer, instant error messaging that brings users back to the exact field. Finally, enabling browser autofill for address and contact fields will reduce typing, lower error rates, and improve completion—typically delivering a measurable lift in conversion with minimal disruption to the customer experience.
